supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for defensive operations, strained for offensive operations. Primary constraint: fuel and ammunition delivery from Algiers (600km) and Tunis port facilities after capture. Moroccan Goumiers highly effective at living off local resources. Division recently re-equipped with mix of French and US Lend-Lease equipment.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Mixed: Coastal plains, mountainous terrain (Dorsale range), agricultural valleys

tactical_doctrine.role: Provisional colonial infantry division formed from French Army of Africa units in Morocco. Equipped with mix of pre-war French equipment and US Lend-Lease materiel. Specialized in mountain warfare and desert operations with Moroccan Tirailleurs (colonial infantry) and Moroccan Goumiers (auxiliary tribal infantry).
special_capabilities: Mountain warfare expertise from Atlas Mountains training
Moroccan Goumiers highly effective at infiltration and night operations
Bilingual command structure (French officers, Arabic-speaking NCOs and troops)
Excellent physical conditioning for mountainous terrain
tactical_innovations: Integration of Moroccan Goumiers (Groupes de Supplétifs Marocains) for reconnaissance and raiding
Use of mule transport in mountainous terrain unsuitable for vehicles
Night infiltration tactics leveraging Moroccan troops' field craft
known_issues: Limited heavy weapons compared to standard divisions
Provisional nature means unit cohesion still developing
Mixed equipment from multiple sources complicates logistics
Communication challenges between French and Moroccan troops
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Moroccan troops well-adapted to North African climate. Goumiers require less water than European troops. Unit employs traditional Moroccan field craft for navigation and survival.

special_rules: Moroccan Goumiers: +1 to night operations and infiltration
Mountain Warfare: No movement penalty in mountainous terrain
Mixed Equipment: -1 to sustained fire due to ammunition diversity
Limited Armor: Cannot conduct armored assaults
Provisional Formation: -1 to initial coordination rolls

source: British Military History - Tunisia 1942-1943 French Divisions
Chemins de mémoire - La campagne de Tunisie
US Army Center of Military History - Tunisia Campaign
Web searches on French March Divisions in Tunisia
required_field_gaps: exact equipment counts for some categories

subordinate_unit_commanders.reason: Regimental commander names not found in available English-language sources. French military archives would be required.
sources_checked: Chemins de mémoire French official source
Wikipedia articles on French Moroccan forces
subordinate_unit_commanders.mitigation: Listed as 'Colonel Unknown' with note. French Service Historique de la Défense archives would have complete records.

exact_equipment_counts.reason: Detailed equipment tables for provisional March Divisions not available in accessible sources. Division was recently re-equipped with mixed French and US Lend-Lease equipment.
exact_equipment_counts.estimate_method: Based on standard French colonial division establishment scaled to 8,200 personnel (reduced from 10,000+ standard division). Equipment mix reflects transition period with both pre-war French and new US Lend-Lease materiel.

tank_allocation.reason: March Divisions were light infantry formations without organic armor. Tank support would come from corps or army-level assets.
tank_allocation.mitigation: Zero tanks is accurate for provisional march divisions.

chief_of_staff.reason: Staff officers below division commander level not documented in accessible sources.
chief_of_staff.mitigation: Omitted from data structure. Would require French military personnel archives.

notes: March Divisions (Divisions de Marche) were provisional formations created from colonial troops for specific campaigns
Unit formed from French Army of Africa units in Morocco after Operation Torch (November 1942)
Equipment mix reflects transition period: pre-war French weapons being supplemented by US Lend-Lease
Moroccan Goumiers (GSM - Groupes de Supplétifs Marocains) provided auxiliary light infantry capabilities
Division participated in final Tunisia Campaign operations April-May 1943
Later served with distinction in Italian Campaign as part of French Expeditionary Corps
Confidence reduced due to limited detailed English-language sources on provisional French colonial formations
